did.abstract: Records of astronomical observatories operated by the University of Michigan including the Detroit Observatory on the Ann Arbor campus (1855-), the Lamont-Hussey Observatory (Bloemfontein, South Africa, 1928-), the McMath-Hulbert Observatory (Portage Lake, Michigan, 1935-1979), the Portage Lake/Peach Mountain Observatory (Dexter, Michigan, 1948-. Records include correspondence files, administrative files, observation notebooks, photographs and architectural drawings.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records (donor #s 1278), 1465, 4765) were transferred in several accessions.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Observatory (University of Michigan) Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The University of Michigan observatories and the Department of Astronomy have their roots in the university presidency of Henry Tappan. Following his inaugural speech in 1852, Tappan was approached by Henry N. Walker, a Detroit resident wishing to become active in university affairs. Tappan encouraged him to raise funds towards the financing of an astronomical observatory. Walker solicited funds from Detroit citizens and in a few months raised $7,000, an amount more than doubled by further subscriptions.

In 1853, Tappan left for Europe to study various educational systems and to procure instruments for the observatory. While in Prussia, Tappan met Franz Brunnow and offered him the directorship of the university's new observatory. Brunnow became the first director of the observatory and a professor of astronomy at the university, remaining until 1863. Brunnow offered the first systematic course in practical astronomy in the world and the new department was one of the first at the University of Michigan to offer graduate level courses.

The observatory building was completed in the summer of 1854, and the instruments were mounted the following winter. A meridian circle was constructed in Berlin and a twelve-inch refracting telescope, at that time the third largest in the world, was constructed by Henry Fritz of New York. President Tappan named the new observatory in honor of the Detroit residents who contributed much of the funding. In 1931 it was renamed the University of Michigan Observatory.

Professor William J. Hussey was made director of the Observatory in 1904 and began work to enlarge and improve it. Observatory equipment had slowly become outclassed by equipment in use elsewhere. Hussey traveled to South Africa in 1923 to select the ideal location for an observatory to map the southern skies. The impetus for this observatory was Robert P. Lamont's gift of a 27-inch refracting telescope in 1910. The Lamont-Hussey Observatory, consisting of a circular telescope room, fifty-six feet in diameter, was dedicated in April 1928 near Bloemfontein, South Africa.

In 1926, Ralph A. Curtiss became chairman of the Department of Astronomy and director of the Observatory. By 1930, the expansion of Ann Arbor created an environment not conducive to astronomical observation. City and university buildings limited the observatory's horizon, smoke and city lights hampered observation, and heavy trains frequently passed within a few hundred yards and jarred sensitive instruments. Additional observatories would be constructed to maintain the quality of the university's research in astronomy.

The McMath-Hulbert Observatory was presented to the university in 1931 by three donors, Francis and Robert McMath and Judge Henry Hulbert. A grant of $20,000 from the Rackham fund, another from the McGregor Fund and private contributions made it possible in 1935 to build a solar tower telescope. This new telescope brought certain suspected phenomena into clear view and disproved a theory about light-pressure advanced in England. For simultaneous recording, a second tower and telescope were constructed. Robert McMath designed all the instruments and buildings. The University of Michigan discontinued its support of the McMath-Hulbert observatory at the end of June 1979.

The university closed its observatory in South Africa upon the retirement of Director Richard A. Rossiter in 1953, bringing the lens and optical equipment back to Michigan. The Department of Astronomy turned to the development of a radio telescope on Peach Mountain near Portage Lake, Michigan, in conjunction with the Office of Naval Research. The Peach Mountain Observatory was begun in 1948, the result of a grant from the McGregor Fund and the university.

The University of Michigan-Dartmouth College-MIT Astronomy Consortium was officially established in 1975, leading to the establishment of the MDM (Michigan-Dartmouth-MIT) Observatory located on Kitt Peak, 50 miles west of Tucson, Arizona, and 6,300 feet above sea level.

Today, the University of Michigan observatories consist of three different sites, operating a total of four major telescopes. These include a 26 meter telescope at a radio observatory located near Ann Arbor, a .6 meter Curtis Schmidt telescope at Cerro Tololo, Chile, and two telescopes of 1.3 and 2.4 meter aperture at the MDM Observatory located on Kitt Peak near Tucson, Arizona. The university continues to maintain small telescopes on the top floor of Angell Hall. Plans also exist for the renovation of the University of Michigan/Detroit Observatory and its telescope.

scopecontent.p: The University of Michigan Observatory records include those of the Lamont-Hussey Observatory, the McMath-Hulbert Observatory, the Peach Mountain Observatory, the Angell Hall Laboratory, the Department of Astronomy, and records of faculty members. Documentation consists of correspondence, astronomical and meteorological observation records, financial records, reports, scrapbooks and blueprints. The collection is divided into seven series: Correspondence, Observatories, Department of Astronomy, Scrapbooks and Clippings, Observation Charts and Notebooks, Photographs, and Blueprints.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (1899-1977; 2.5 linear ft.) includes correspondence of observatory directors William J. Hussey, Ralph H. Curtiss, Heber D. Curtis, W. Carl Rufus, A.D. Maxwell, Leo Goldberg, Robert R. McMath, and R.A. Rossiter. Correspondents include Robert P. Lamont, Harlow Shapley, and Frank E. Robbins.

The Observatories series (1892-1985; 4.7 linear ft) is divided into five alphabetically arranged sub-series, representing the separate observatories operated by or affiliated with the university. Researchers should note that there is some overlap among the observatories within each of the sub-series.

The Angell Hall Laboratory sub-series (1925-1927, and undated) documents the laboratory and students' observatory of the Department of Astronomy located on the fifth floor and roof of Angell Hall. The sub-series includes information on equipment and facility use.

The Detroit Observatory sub-series (1892-1944) documents the University of Michigan's first observatory, located in Ann Arbor, Michigan, whose name was changed to the University of Michigan Observatory in 1931. It includes materials documenting the observatory grounds and equipment, as well as notes and writings of staff members. Also included in this subseries is a log book, prepared by consultant Christopher Ray documenting the 1997 restoration of the 1856 Fitz 12-inch refractor

scopecontent.p: The Lamont-Hussey Observatory sub-series (1918-1963) documents the university observatory located in South Africa. It includes correspondence and observations of observatory director R.H. Curtiss.

did.unittitle: Correspondence, R.A. Rossiter to R.H. Curtiss
Correspondence, R.H. Curtiss to R.A. Rossiter
Report of W.J. Hussey's South African Trip 1924

scopecontent.p: The McMath-Hulbert Observatory sub-series (1937-1985) documents the university observatory located in Portage Lake, Michigan. It includes the files of Orren Mohler, director of the observatory until its closing in 1979. This sub-series also includes materials accessioned in 1980, which are located separately in box 15.

scopecontent.p: The Portage Lake/Peach Mountain Observatory sub-series (1947-1971) documents the university observatory located near Dexter, Michigan. It includes materials related to construction of the facility.

did.unittitle: Movement of Schmidt Telescope to Cerro Tololo, Chile 1965-1971

scopecontent.p: The Department of Astronomy series (1908-1963; 1.2 linear ft.) documents the Department of Astronomy at the University of Michigan. The series includes budgets, regents communications, and course materials. It also includes materials written by and about faculty and students, notably the files of Dean B. McLaughlin, a professor and astronomer at the university from the 1930s to the 1960s. The Orren Mohler files in the McMath-Hulbert Observatory sub-series also include related course material. Researchers should also note the existence of a separate University of Michigan Department of Astronomy record group containing more recent departmental documentation.

did.unittitle: Correspondence and reports: American Astronomical Society
Correspondence and reports: International Astronomical Union
Method of Recording the Daily Weather Observations in Permanent "Meteorological Observations" Record undated
Spectrographic Studies of Eclipsing Binaries, a dissertation, post-1922
The Sky, prepared by Robert Petrie, edited by Donald Ries and Aimee Lambie, 1934

scopecontent.p: The Scrapbooks and Clippings series (1921-1970; .6 linear ft.) covers the years 1921-1970 and documents faculty, staff, facilities, and changes in the university's observatories and the Department of Astronomy.

The Observation Charts and Notebooks series (1855-1944; 6 linear ft.) includes astronomical and meteorological observations made by J.M. Shaeberle, Asaph Hall Jr., William J. Hussey, C.S. Woodard, and S.D. Townley. The series is divided in three main files: Double Star Charts, Astronomical Observation Notebooks, and Meteorological Observations.

The Double Star Charts: Northern Hemisphere files consists of the observation notebooks of William J. Hussey which note the existence and location of double stars. Some related notebooks appear in the astronomical observation notebooks subseries and in the Lamont-Hussey Observatory subseries.

The Astronomical Observation Notebooks consist of notebooks and journals maintained by university and non-university affiliated observers dating from 1855 to 1923. The observation volumes also contain a journal used as a letter book by Asaph Hall which include his resignation letter noting problems facing the observatory. Some volumes also comment on equipment needs.

The Meteorological Observations consist of notebooks maintained by university and non-university affiliated observers. The notebooks, particularly those from 1908 to 1944, offer detailed daily weather data for the Ann Arbor area.

did.unittitle: Equatorial Observations of Comets and Planets 1857-1865, 1879
Miscellaneous Notebooks, containing Corrections, Factors, Class Notes, Calculations, ca. 1879-1905, 1932-1941
Notebooks of W.J. Hussey, containing observations of Mars, Eclipses and Aurora of the Sun, Double Stars, and Miscellaneous notes

scopecontent.p: The Photographs series (1908-1963; 1 linear ft.) consists of photographs (including oversize photos) documenting the University of Michigan observatories. These include images of buildings, observatories, telescopes, faculty, staff, benefactors and visitors. An oversize group photograph of the 46th meeting of the American Astronomical Society at the Perkins Observatory in Delaware, Ohio includes Dean McLaughlin, Orrin Mohler, and Hazel Losh.

scopecontent.p: The final series, Blueprints (1907-1967) contains over 350 oversize architectural plans and mechanical drawings of university observatories and telescopes. The bulk of the drawings are from the period 1907-1911 and document the 36 inch reflecting telescope in the Detroit Observatory. Other material documents the McMath-Hulbert Observatory, the Lamont Refractor, and the Peach Mountain Observatory.
